What is the most popular Ghibli movie?

When I decided to start this blog, I was curious about the most popular Ghibli movie. I searched online for the popular Ghibli movie in Japan and North America. The difference in the results was interesting to me, so I’m sharing the results and my insights.

  • North America

Commonalities

Commonly popular Ghibli movies include Spirited Away, Princess Mononoke, Howl’s Moving Castle, My Neighbor Totoro, Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind, Castle in the Sky, and Kiki’s Delivery Service.

Grave of the Fireflies

“Grave of the Fireflies” ranked 6th in IMDb’s poll, while in Japanese polls, it placed 19th. The film tells the story of two young siblings living through World War II, based on a true story, making it truly heartbreaking. Based on the poll results, I believe Japanese audiences view this movie more as an educational piece about wartime rather than just a piece of Studio Ghibli. I recall watching this film in elementary school, and it left a deep impact on me. Many reviews on IMDb label it as a ‘must-see,’ and I believe watching it can serve as a reminder to prevent future wars, despite its depressing nature.

Red Turtle

Another interesting point is that “Red Turtle” secured 9th place in IMDb’s poll, despite being relatively unknown in Japan. “Red Turtle” is an international co-production involving several French film companies and is unique in that it lacks any dialogue. The film premiered at the 69th Cannes Film Festival and received nominations, including one for Best Animated Feature at the 89th Academy Awards.
It’s the only Studio Ghibli movie without dialogue, and I’m genuinely intrigued to see what it’s like. I’ll definitely be giving it a watch soon!

Recommendation

On the other hand, “The Cat Returns” appears to be less well-known in North America. I highly recommend this film, especially for cat lovers. It’s lighter in tone compared to some other Ghibli movies, and the adorable cats will surely captivate cat lovers’ hearts. Since it’s connected to “Whisper of the Heart,” exploring those connections adds another way to enjoy this film.
